item.title: Tianjin Explosions Were Result of Mismanagement, China Finds
item.description: Citing dereliction of duty, Chinese cabinet officials vowed to punish 123 government workers in connection with the blasts in August, which killed 165 people.
item.category: Rui Hai International Logistics Co Ltd
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ
item.media:description: The aftermath of explosions in Tianjin, China, in 2015. A new report described the blasts as a man-made disaster that caused $1.1 billion in damage.

item.title: No End to Scrutiny Over Millions Sent to Malaysian Leader’s Accounts
item.description: The halt of an official investigation has not quieted questions over how hundreds of millions of dollars ended up in the accounts of Prime Minister Najib Razak.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Prime Minister Najib Razak of Malaysia appeared on television to announce revisions to the fiscal budget last month.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: A Democratic Diplomat, at Ease With Both Guerrillas and the G.O.P.
item.description: Bernard Aronson, who played a role in American policy in Nicaragua and El Salvador, is back in the diplomatic field, trying to end the guerrilla conflict in Colombia.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:credit: Lexey Swall for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bernard Aronson, the United States envoy to the Colombia peace talks, in his office in Washington.

item.title: In Historic Move, Pope to Meet With Leader of Russian Orthodox Church
item.description: The meeting, scheduled for Feb. 12 in Cuba, will be the first meeting between a pope and the Russian patriarch since the Great Schism of 1054.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO and JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: Pope Francis at the Vatican on Tuesday. For Francis, the meeting with the leader of the Russian Orthodox Church is the result of delicate and sustained diplomacy.

item.title: ISIS Using Migrant Crisis to Smuggle In Terrorists, German Official Says
item.description: An Algerian man who was detained on suspicion of plotting a terrorist attack entered the country was staying at a shelter for asylum applicants, the domestic intelligence chief said.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Migrants waiting for registration in Berlin on Friday. An initially warm welcome in Germany has soured after suspicions that terrorists could enter along with refugees.

item.title: Opinion: What You Get When You Mix Chickens, China and Climate Change
item.description: The pathogens that frighten me most are novel strains of avian influenza.
item.dc:creator: SONIA SHAH

item.title: To Build a Ski Resort Under U.N. Sanctions, North Korea Turned to China
item.description: China told a United Nations panel that sanctions barring the sale of luxury goods did not apply because skiing is a “normal activity” in North Korea.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ and YUFAN HUANG
item.media:description: The Masikryong ski resort in North Korea. Imported equipment for it was manufactured by an Austrian company and sold to China.

item.title: Myanmar Talks Could Open Door to Presidency for Aung San Suu Kyi
item.description: The democracy leader’s party has offered senior government posts to the military as part of a possible deal, two top party officials said.
item.dc:creator: WAI MOE and THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Military representatives of Parliament registering for the first session of the upper house at the capital, Naypyidaw, on Wednesday.

item.title: In Iran, State-Backed Companies Win From Lifted Sanctions
item.description: While major conglomerates profit, little or nothing is trickling down to the lower levels of Iran’s beleaguered but still enormous private sector.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:credit: Stephane De Sakutin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Hassan Rouhani of Iran, center, at the Élysée Palace in Paris with President François Hollande, right, last month.

item.title: Sinosphere: Ties to Chinese State Media Overshadow an Election Campaign in U.S.
item.description: Phillip Yin, a candidate for lieutenant governor of Washington State, was until last year a news anchor for CCTV, the Chinese state television broadcaster.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ
item.media:description: Phillip Yin, former anchor at CCTV America, announced in January that he was running for lieutenant governor of Washington State.

item.title: 5 Czechs Who Were Missing in Lebanon Arrive Home
item.description: The joyful response to their return has been tempered by revelations that Prague seems to have freed two terrorism suspects to secure their release.
item.dc:creator: HANA de GOEIJ
item.media:description: Ali Taan Fayad, a citizen of Lebanon who is wanted by the United States, at a court in Prague in 2014.

item.title: Letter From Europe: A Ruling in Alexander Litvinenko’s Poisoning, but No Justice
item.description: Marina Litvinenko, the widow of the former K.G.B. officer who was poisoned in London, is pushing for sanctions against members of the Kremlin elite.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: The grave of Alexander V. Litvinenko, who was poisoned in 2006, at Highgate Cemetery in London.

item.title: world briefing: Czech Republic: Detainees Return Home From Lebanon
item.description: Five Czechs who had been missing and presumed kidnapped in Lebanon last year came home on Thursday after the Czech government freed two Lebanese citizens who were wanted by the United States.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: world briefing: Nigeria: Separatist Groups Deny Any Role in Ship’s Hijacking
item.description: Claims that the ship was boarded last week by separatists are probably a cover to lend legitimacy to a kidnapping for ransom, a maritime security expert said.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: world briefing: Somalia: Residue From Explosives Found in Jet, Airline Says
item.description: The top executive of the airline, whose jetliner was damaged in an explosion shortly after takeoff this week, cautioned that the findings were inconclusive.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Poland: New Inquiry Opened Into 2010 Crash
item.description: The plane crash, in Russia, killed President Lech Kaczynski, and Poland’s defense minister said that evidence pointing to Russian involvement had been covered up in an earlier investigation.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Blood Banks Use Caution With Travelers From Zika Zones
item.description: Potential donors are being asked not to give blood if within the last month they have visited a country in which the Zika virus is spreading.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: CATHERINE SAINT LOUIS

item.title: Obama Praises Colombia’s Peace Efforts With Rebels and Seeks Big Aid Increase
item.description: The Colombian government is expected to sign a final peace agreement with FARC guerrillas by March 23, bringing an end to the longest civil war in Latin America.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER

item.title: An Italian’s Brutal Death in Egypt Chills Relations
item.description: The body of Giulio Regeni, a doctoral candidate who was doing research, was found on the edge of Cairo with signs of torture methods frequently associated with the security forces.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: Giulio Regeni in an undated photo from social media.

item.title: Government Forces, Backed by Russian Jets, Advance in Syria
item.description: The government’s recent gains have diminished pressure on President Bashar al-Assad to compromise in negotiations.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
